pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 378, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 365, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 171, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
0625/22 February/March 2025 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 505, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 278, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 226, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 905, 520]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 218, 561]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 564, 570, 610]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 549, 90]]<|/det|> The diagram shows three forces acting on an object. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 100, 664, 180]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 654, 211]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the resultant force acting on the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 223, 144, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 223, 200, 240]]<|/det|> 2.0N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 223, 363, 240]]<|/det|> B 10N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 223, 527, 240]]<|/det|> C 14N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 223, 693, 240]]<|/det|> D 16N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 269, 95, 287]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 440, 286]]<|/det|> Which row defines speed and velocity? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 760, 426]]<|/det|>
speedvelocity
Adistance travelled in a given directionspeed per unit time
Bdistance travelled per unit timespeed in a given direction
Cdistance travelled in a given directionspeed in a given direction
Ddistance travelled per unit timespeed per unit time
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 96, 473]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 502, 471]]<|/det|> The graph shows the journey of a motorcyclist. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 920, 516]]<|/det|> Which section of the graph shows the time when the motorcyclist is stationary at some traffic lights? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 527, 690, 680]]<|/det|>

EarthMoon
mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 359, 94, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 528, 376]]<|/det|> The load–extension graph for a material is shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 517, 407]]<|/det|> Which point indicates the limit of proportionality? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 418, 660, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 622, 94, 641]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 622, 752, 640]]<|/det|> An object of mass \(4.0 \text{kg}\) is moving with a velocity of \(3.0 \text{m/s}\) in a straight line. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 428, 670]]<|/det|> What is the momentum of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 681, 737, 698]]<|/det|> **A** \(0.75 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) **B** \(1.3 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) **C** \(12 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) **D** \(24 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A tall cylinder is partly filled with two liquids, which do not mix. The two liquids have different densities. A student measures the pressure due to the liquids at different depths.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 113, 697, 276]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 768, 305]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the liquid pressure varies between positions P and Q?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 314, 845, 623]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 650, 94, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 651, 670, 668]]<|/det|>
A tennis ball with momentum \(2.3 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) is struck by a tennis racket.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 681, 636, 698]]<|/det|>
The racket causes the direction of motion of the ball to reverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
The racket exerts an average force of 1500 N during the impact with the ball. The racket and ball are in contact with each other for a time of 0.0024 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 757, 788, 774]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the momentum of the ball as it leaves the tennis racket?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 744, 803]]<|/det|>
A \(1.3 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) B \(3.6 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) C \(5.9 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\) D \(8.6 \text{kg} \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 447, 90]]<|/det|> A car is travelling at a speed of \(8.0m / s.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 504, 120]]<|/det|> The kinetic energy stored in the car is \(32 000 \text{J}.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 777, 149]]<|/det|> What is the kinetic energy stored in the car when its speed increases to \(16 \text{m/s}\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 735, 178]]<|/det|> A 16 000 J B 32 000 J C 64 000 J D 130 000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 206, 107, 225]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 650, 223]]<|/det|> The Sun is **not** the primary source of energy for which resource? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 235, 175, 250]]<|/det|> A oil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 261, 191, 276]]<|/det|> B tidal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 196, 302]]<|/det|> C wind <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 313, 200, 328]]<|/det|> D wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 357, 107, 376]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 357, 919, 390]]<|/det|> An experiment is done to compare the rate of conduction of thermal energy in metal and plastic spoons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 803, 419]]<|/det|> An ice cube is placed on one end of each spoon and the other end is heated gently. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 429, 816, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 534, 627, 551]]<|/det|> Which row has the correct prediction and correct explanation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
predictionexplanation
AThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the metal spoon.Metal is a good conductor.
BThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the metal spoon.Plastic is a good conductor.
CThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the plastic spoon.Metal is a poor conductor.
DThe ice cube would melt more quickly on the plastic spoon.Plastic is a poor conductor.
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 720, 107, 738]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 919, 752]]<|/det|> Four students determine the efficiency of four different electrical devices. The teacher knows that one student has made a mistake in the calculation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 455, 781]]<|/det|> Which value for efficiency is **not** correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 151, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 793, 201, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 793, 317, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 793, 377, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 793, 527, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 793, 703, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 793, 705, 811]]<|/det|> D <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 793, 755, 811]]<|/det|> 102%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 615, 90]]<|/det|>
A sample of gas is sealed inside a container of fixed volume.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 452, 120]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the gas is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 133, 658, 150]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why the pressure of the gas increases?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 740, 178]]<|/det|>
A The gas particles collide with the walls of the container more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 188, 484, 204]]<|/det|>
B The mass of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 214, 604, 230]]<|/det|>
C The number of gas particles in the container increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 632, 256]]<|/det|>
D The time between collisions of the gas particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 284, 107, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 825, 301]]<|/det|>
A student does an experiment to determine the specific heat capacity of a metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 460, 330]]<|/det|>
She records the following measurements.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 343, 386, 360]]<|/det|>
\[\text{energy supplied} = 12 \text{kJ}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 369, 404, 386]]<|/det|>
\[\text{initial temperature} = 20^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 395, 396, 412]]<|/det|>
\[\text{final temperature} = 45^{\circ}\text{C}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 422, 420, 438]]<|/det|>
\[\text{mass of metal block} = 600 \text{g}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 451, 553, 467]]<|/det|>
What is the specific heat capacity of the metal block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 314, 495]]<|/det|>
A \(8.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 270, 521]]<|/det|>
B \(0.80 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 265, 548]]<|/det|>
C \(180 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 265, 574]]<|/det|>
D \(800 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 602, 107, 619]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 918, 634]]<|/det|>
A metal block is left overnight in a cool, shady room. In the morning, the metal block is moved into warm surroundings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 648, 652, 664]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the metal block is correct in the morning?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 553, 692]]<|/det|>
A The internal energy of the metal block increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 702, 537, 718]]<|/det|>
B The temperature of the metal block decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 728, 613, 744]]<|/det|>
C Convection transfers energy throughout the metal block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 384, 770]]<|/det|>
D The metal contracts slightly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 800, 107, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 918, 847]]<|/det|>
A fixed mass of gas is contained within a sealed syringe at a pressure of \(100 \text{kPa}\). The plunger is slowly moved until the pressure is \(80 \text{kPa}\). The final volume of the gas is \(50 \text{cm}^3\). The temperature of the gas does **not** change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 860, 608, 876]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the gas before the plunger is moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 887, 722, 903]]<|/det|>
A \(0.25 \text{cm}^3\) B \(40 \text{cm}^3\) C \(63 \text{cm}^3\) D \(160 \text{cm}^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the more energetic water molecules escaping from the surface of liquid water. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 115, 683, 231]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 244, 352, 261]]<|/det|> What is this process called? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 295, 290]]<|/det|> A Brownian motion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 265, 315]]<|/det|> B condensation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 326, 252, 341]]<|/det|> C evaporation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 245, 367]]<|/det|> D conduction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 396, 107, 414]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 415, 412]]<|/det|> A hot object emits thermal radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 812, 443]]<|/det|> Which row describes two changes that both reduce the rate of emission of radiation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 567, 584]]<|/det|>
surface areasurface temperature
Aincreasedincreased
Bincreasedreduced
Creducedincreased
Dreducedreduced
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 611, 107, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 611, 759, 628]]<|/det|> The frequency of a wave is doubled. The speed of the wave does **not** change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 641, 499, 658]]<|/det|> What happens to the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 670, 408, 686]]<|/det|> A It becomes four times as large. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 696, 316, 712]]<|/det|> B It does **not** change. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 722, 241, 738]]<|/det|> C It doubles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 749, 230, 764]]<|/det|> D It halves. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 793, 107, 811]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 490, 810]]<|/det|> Which statement about ultrasound is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 821, 759, 838]]<|/det|> A It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 848, 749, 864]]<|/det|> B It has a higher frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 874, 749, 890]]<|/det|> C It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a longitudinal wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 900, 742, 916]]<|/det|> D It has a lower frequency than audible sound and it is a transverse wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 745, 90]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the image produced by a plane mirror is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 150, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 101, 301, 119]]<|/det|>
The image is real.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 327, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 125, 327, 144]]<|/det|>
The image is upright.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 144, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 153, 495, 170]]<|/det|>
The image is the same size as the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 139, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 179, 918, 211]]<|/det|>
The distance from the image to the mirror is the same as the distance from the object to the mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 240, 107, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 625, 257]]<|/det|>
A ray of light is incident on a boundary between air and water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 269, 670, 286]]<|/det|>
Under which conditions is the ray of light totally internally reflected?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 138, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 297, 888, 314]]<|/det|>
The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air–water boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 323, 918, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 320, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
The ray, initially in the air, is incident on the air–water boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 138, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 363, 912, 380]]<|/det|>
The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water–air boundary at any angle of incidence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 138, 407]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 390, 918, 422]]<|/det|>
The ray, initially in the water, is incident on the water–air boundary at an angle of incidence greater than the critical angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 450, 107, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 590, 467]]<|/det|>
A converging lens is used to make an image on a screen.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[294, 478, 700, 623]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 497, 656]]<|/det|>
Which type of image is formed on the screen?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 295, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 668, 295, 684]]<|/det|>
real and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 285, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 694, 285, 710]]<|/det|>
real and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 312, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 720, 312, 736]]<|/det|>
virtual and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 746, 303, 762]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 746, 303, 762]]<|/det|>
virtual and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A negatively charged rod is brought near to a metal sphere. A positive charge develops on the surface of the metal sphere closest to the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 220, 135]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 145, 707, 163]]<|/det|>
A Electrons in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 172, 698, 189]]<|/det|>
B Electrons in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 198, 764, 215]]<|/det|>
C Positive charges in the sphere are attracted by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 758, 241]]<|/det|>
D Positive charges in the sphere are repelled by the negatively charged rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 268, 107, 287]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 768, 286]]<|/det|>
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell is defined in terms of which quantities?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 720, 315]]<|/det|>
A the energy transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 324, 724, 341]]<|/det|>
B the energy transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 714, 367]]<|/det|>
C the power transferred by the cell in moving charge around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 376, 718, 393]]<|/det|>
D the power transferred by the cell in moving voltage around the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 420, 107, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 801, 438]]<|/det|>
A resistor of resistance \(R\) is connected to a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 399, 468]]<|/det|>
There is a current \(I\) in the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 421, 497]]<|/det|>
Power \(P\) is dissipated by the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 511, 420, 528]]<|/det|>
In time \(t,\) the energy transferred is \(E.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 541, 356, 558]]<|/det|>
Which expression is correct?

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 710, 600]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A}\quad E = IVt\qquad \mathbf{B}\quad E = PI t\qquad \mathbf{C}\quad P = VIR\qquad \mathbf{D}\quad P = \frac{V}{R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 629, 107, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 629, 797, 647]]<|/det|>
A copper wire of length \(80 \text{cm}\) and cross-sectional area \(0.20 \text{mm}^2\) has resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 777, 676]]<|/det|>
Which length of copper wire of cross-sectional area \(0.40 \text{mm}^2\) has resistance \(R\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 687, 715, 705]]<|/det|>
A \(10 \text{cm}\) B \(20 \text{cm}\) C \(40 \text{cm}\) D \(160 \text{cm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 905, 90]]<|/det|>
Four identical resistors are connected to a battery as shown. Each resistor has a value of \(120\Omega\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 102, 611, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 313, 330]]<|/det|>
Resistor \(\mathsf{R}_4\) is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 828, 360]]<|/det|>
Which effect does removing this resistor have on the effective resistance of the circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 141, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 371, 500, 388]]<|/det|>
The effective resistance does **not** change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 141, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 399, 514, 415]]<|/det|>
The effective resistance decreases by \(20\Omega\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 141, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 426, 505, 443]]<|/det|>
The effective resistance increases by \(20\Omega\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 141, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 454, 524, 471]]<|/det|>
The effective resistance decreases by \(120\Omega\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 500, 88]]<|/det|> The resistors in the circuit shown are identical. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 420, 118]]<|/det|> The reading on voltmeter \(\mathsf{V}_2\) is \(1.5\mathsf{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 133, 426, 148]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_2\) is \(0.50\mathsf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 163, 426, 178]]<|/det|> The reading on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_3\) is \(0.25\mathsf{A}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 191, 664, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 446, 583, 462]]<|/det|> What are the readings on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_1\) and voltmeter \(\mathsf{V}_1\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 475, 503, 603]]<|/det|>
ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_1/\mathsf{A}\)voltmeter \(\mathsf{V}_1/\mathsf{V}\)
A0.251.5
B0.253.0
C0.751.5
D0.753.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 620, 90]]<|/det|>
A wire is moved in the region between the poles of a magnet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 101, 645, 225]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 241, 377, 257]]<|/det|>
A current is induced in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 272, 422, 288]]<|/det|>
In which direction is the wire moved?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 490, 316]]<|/det|>
**A** horizontally from the N pole to the S pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 490, 342]]<|/det|>
**B** horizontally from the S pole to the N pole

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 500, 368]]<|/det|>
**C** perpendicularly into the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 378, 519, 394]]<|/det|>
**D** perpendicularly out of the plane of the paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 422, 104, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 919, 454]]<|/det|>
A fixed resistor is connected to the secondary coil of a step-down transformer. The transformer is 100% efficient.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 464, 724, 604]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 618, 873, 634]]<|/det|>
The variable resistor is adjusted so that the current in the fixed resistor decreases by 0.25A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 648, 574, 664]]<|/det|>
What is the change to the current in the primary circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 343, 692]]<|/det|>
**A** It decreases by 0.25A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 703, 421, 718]]<|/det|>
**B** It decreases by less than 0.25A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 728, 430, 744]]<|/det|>
**C** It decreases by more than 0.25A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 320, 770]]<|/det|>
**D** There is no change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 856, 88]]<|/det|> An electrical device changes the voltage of an electrical supply from \(240 \text{V}\) a.c. to \(20 \text{V}\) a.c. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 285, 117]]<|/det|> What is this device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 250, 145]]<|/det|> **A** a generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 157, 212, 171]]<|/det|> **B** a relay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 266, 197]]<|/det|> **C** a transformer <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 248, 223]]<|/det|> **D** a voltmeter <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 254, 104, 271]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 919, 300]]<|/det|> An a.c. generator is set up so that its coil of wire is perpendicular to the magnetic field. The coil of wire is rotated slowly to produce an alternating electromotive force (e.m.f.). A graph of the induced e.m.f. against time is plotted as the coil rotates. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 311, 742, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 452, 739, 468]]<|/det|> Which section of the graph represents a rotation of three-quarters of a turn? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 685, 495]]<|/det|> **A** OP **B** OQ **C** OR **D** OS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 528, 104, 546]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 919, 565]]<|/det|> A uranium nucleus \(^{238}_{92}\mathrm{U}\) decays to form thorium by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle. Thorium decays to protactinium by emitting a \(\beta\) -particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 579, 823, 594]]<|/det|> Which row gives the atomic number and mass number of this isotope of protactinium? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 480, 736]]<|/det|>
atomic numbermass number
A89234
B90235
C91234
D95235

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 784, 91]]<|/det|> Which row shows what happens when a nucleus decays by emitting a \(\beta\) -particle? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 573, 291]]<|/det|>
change in the nucleusparticle emitted
Aa neutron changes to a proton and an electronelectron
Ba neutron changes to a proton and an electronproton
Ca proton changes to a neutron and an electronelectron
Da proton changes to a neutron and an electronneutron
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 320, 107, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 320, 920, 354]]<|/det|> Which precaution does **not** always reduce a scientist's exposure when working with sources of ionising radiation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 364, 826, 381]]<|/det|> **A** ensuring the scientist only works with sources of radiation that have long half-lives <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 747, 407]]<|/det|> **B** increasing the distance between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 416, 724, 433]]<|/det|> **C** limiting the time for which the scientist handles the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 725, 459]]<|/det|> **D** placing a lead shield between the scientist and the source of radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 486, 107, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 486, 868, 503]]<|/det|> A detector is placed near a radioactive isotope and records a count rate of 700 counts/min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 516, 404, 533]]<|/det|> The half-life of the isotope is 8 min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 562, 564]]<|/det|> The average background count rate is 60 counts/ min. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 577, 626, 594]]<|/det|> What is the count rate measured by the detector after 16 min? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 605, 288, 621]]<|/det|> **A** 100 counts/min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 632, 288, 647]]<|/det|> **B** 160 counts/min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 288, 673]]<|/det|> **C** 175 counts/min <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 684, 288, 699]]<|/det|> **D** 220 counts/min

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> The nucleus of an isotope of nitrogen, N, absorbs a neutron. It then decays into an isotope of carbon, C, and emits x. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[404, 117, 596, 138]]<|/det|> \[{}_{0}^{1}\mathrm{n} + {}^{14}_{7}\mathrm{N}\rightarrow {}^{14}_{6}\mathrm{C} + \mathrm{x}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 207, 170]]<|/det|> What is x? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 183, 234, 199]]<|/det|> **A** \(\alpha\) -particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 234, 226]]<|/det|> **B** \(\beta\) -particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 242, 253]]<|/det|> **C** \(\gamma\) -radiation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 263, 210, 279]]<|/det|> **D** proton <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 308, 107, 326]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 919, 339]]<|/det|> The graph shows how the strength of the Earth's gravitational field varies as the distance from the Earth's surface increases. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 350, 683, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 920, 592]]<|/det|> Which row describes the effect that this has on the mass and on the weight of an object as it moves further away from the Earth's surface? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 604, 507, 731]]<|/det|>
mass of objectweight of object
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesunchanged
Cunchangeddecreases
Dunchangedunchanged

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A student plots a graph of the speed of different galaxies moving away from the Earth against their distance from the Earth.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 114, 863, 359]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 880, 388]]<|/det|>
Using the best straight line shown on the graph, what is the value of the Hubble constant \(H_0?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 270, 500]]<|/det|>
A \(2.0 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\) B \(2.2 \times 10^{-18} \text{s}^{-1}\) C \(4.5 \times 10^{17} \text{s}\) D \(5.0 \times 10^{17} \text{s}\)
